nodes.text: PCA-based dimensionality reduction improves machine learning performance for hyperspectral optical imaging soil moisture estimation
Hyperspectral optical imaging produces high-dimensional, highly correlated spectral data that create computational and generalization challenges for ML
Because bands are strongly correlated, the intrinsic or virtual dimensionality is often much lower than the nominal number of spectral bands
Dataset: 679 samples from a 2017 field campaign on bare soil, each with soil moisture target and 125 hyperspectral bands (450-950 nm) acquired by a Cubert UHD 285
Data preparation: imported into Python, features X = 125 bands, target y = soil moisture, standardized with StandardScaler, train/test split with test_size=0.3 and random_state=42
PCA applied to standardized spectral features; number of components chosen to retain >99% cumulative variance, yielding two principal components (PC1, PC2)
Selection evidence: covariance matrix analysis, eigenvalue distribution, and scree plot show sharp variance drop after PC2 supporting two-component choice
Projection onto PC1 and PC2 reveals clearer separation and clustering of samples by normalized soil moisture compared to higher-dimensional space
Random Forest regression trained on PCA-transformed data using sklearn with 100 trees, test_size=0.3, random_state=42, performance measured by R2
Model performance: Random Forest trained on PCA-reduced features achieved R2 = 0.947 (94.7% explained variance) for soil moisture estimation
PCA reduction to two components reduces redundancy and data complexity, improves visualization and computational efficiency, while preserving strong predictive capability
Conclusion: PCA is an effective baseline dimensionality reduction strategy for hyperspectral imaging workflows, enabling interpretable and scalable ML models without compromising accuracy
Limitation and future work: results are demonstrated on a single soil moisture dataset and PCA; further evaluation of alternative feature extraction methods and diverse sensors/scenarios is needed
